alt_statements.statement: As someone who’s spent a lifetime in social work and community service, I believe immigration policy should be grounded in basic human dignity, fairness, and practical compassion. We should have a clear, achievable path to citizenship for people who work, pay taxes, follow the law, and put down roots here, while prioritizing family unity and protections for refugees and vulnerable people. At the same time, we need a well-run, transparent system that uses modern tools to process applications efficiently and uphold reasonable border security without demonizing those who come seeking a better life.

Immigration policy should prioritize the safety, stability, and economic well-being of American families, with strict enforcement of existing laws and secure borders as the foundation. I support a clear, structured, and demanding legal path to citizenship that requires background checks, steady work, English proficiency, and respect for our laws and values. We’re a nation of immigrants, but we’re also a nation of laws, and any system needs to be fair to those who follow the rules and protect opportunities for citizens first.

As a liberal, health-conscious professional who works every day with people from many backgrounds, I believe immigration policy should be guided by fairness, human dignity, and economic reality. We should have a clear, efficient, and humane path to citizenship that prioritizes family unity, respects the rule of law, and recognizes the contributions immigrants make to our communities and workforce. I support strong due process protections at the border, smart security measures based on evidence rather than fear, and opportunities for long-term undocumented residents who contribute and follow the law to earn legal status and eventual citizenship.

Como inmigrante cubana que ha trabajado duro muchos años en este país, creo que la política migratoria debe ser ordenada y respetuosa de las leyes, pero también compasiva con quienes vienen a trabajar, aportar y criar a sus familias en paz. Pienso que el camino a la ciudadanía debería exigir buen comportamiento, trabajo constante, aprender el idioma y pagar impuestos, y a cambio ofrecer una oportunidad real de salir de las sombras y formar parte plena de esta nación.

As someone who works in healthcare and sees every day how much our system relies on immigrants, I believe our immigration policy should be fair, orderly, and humane, with clear rules that are actually enforced. We should make the legal path to citizenship more accessible for people who work hard, follow the law, and contribute to their communities, while maintaining reasonable security checks. I also think we need to treat families with dignity and respect throughout the process, regardless of where they come from.

I think immigration policy should balance compassion with practicality: we ought to welcome people who want to work hard, follow the law, and contribute to our communities, but we also need clear, consistently enforced rules and secure borders. A fair path to citizenship should include background checks, paying taxes, learning English, and a reasonable waiting period, without making the process so complicated or expensive that only the wealthy can manage it.

Immigration policy should balance compassion with clear, enforceable rules, creating an efficient, transparent path to citizenship for people who work hard, follow the law, and contribute to our communities and economy. As someone who grew up in New Mexico and works in a field built on fairness, I believe we need stronger due process protections, humane treatment at the border, and a streamlined system that prioritizes family unity, labor needs, and long-term residents who are already part of the social fabric.

As someone who grew up in a mixed, immigrant-heavy community and cares a lot about fairness and opportunity, I think immigration policy should be guided by human rights, family unity, and a clear, realistic path to citizenship. We should protect Dreamers and long-term undocumented residents who contribute to our communities, make the process less expensive and confusing, and treat asylum seekers with dignity instead of suspicion. At the same time, we can maintain secure, orderly borders through smart, humane enforcement that doesn’t criminalize people simply for wanting a better life. Overall, our policies should reflect America’s values of inclusion, hard work, and second chances, not fear and scapegoating.

As someone who came here from Korea and became a citizen through a long, difficult process, I believe immigration policy should be firm, fair, and humane, with clear rules that are actually followed and not twisted by politics. We should prioritize family unity, protection for refugees, and a realistic, orderly path to citizenship for people who work, pay taxes, and contribute to their communities. At the same time, we need strong, efficient border and visa enforcement so the system is trusted and people who follow the law aren’t punished for the chaos caused by those who don’t.

As a conservative, family-oriented mom and a proud American, I believe immigration policy should prioritize border security, the rule of law, and an orderly, merit-based system. We should welcome those who come legally, work hard, share our values, and contribute to our economy, while ensuring that the path to citizenship is clear, fair, and doesn’t reward cutting in line.

I think immigration rules should be fair and kind, because my church teaches that everyone is a child of God and deserves to be treated with respect. We should have strong safety checks so people follow the laws, but we should also make it possible for good, hardworking families to become citizens and stay together. Kids who grow up here, go to school here, and feel American should have a clear and simple way to become citizens too.

Immigration policy should be firm, orderly, and grounded in respect for the law, because becoming an American is a serious commitment that should not be taken lightly. As someone who came here from Cuba and went through the legal process to become a citizen, I believe the path to citizenship must require following the rules, learning English, understanding our history and institutions, and showing loyalty to this country. I support legal immigration for those who are willing to work hard, integrate into our communities, and accept our values, but I think illegal entry should have real consequences and not be rewarded with automatic benefits or easy citizenship.

I think immigration rules should be fair and kind, because my church teaches that we should welcome and help people, especially families and kids. People who come here to work hard, follow the laws, and want to be good neighbors should have a clear and not-too-confusing way to become citizens.

I think immigration policy should be fair and organized so people who follow the rules and really want to contribute can have a clear path to citizenship. Since my family’s been in the U.S. for a long time but I like learning about different cultures, I believe we should welcome immigrants who respect our laws and values, while also making sure the process is safe and not chaotic.

I think immigration policy should be strict but fair: secure the border, enforce the laws we already have, and make sure people who follow the rules and work hard have a clear, predictable path to citizenship. We should prioritize folks who want to contribute, respect our laws and culture, and are willing to learn English, while keeping the process efficient and not buried in red tape.

As someone who believes in both the rule of law and basic fairness, I think immigration policy should focus on secure, well-enforced borders while also providing a clear, realistic path to citizenship for people who follow the rules, work hard, and contribute to their communities. We ought to prioritize background checks, employment and language requirements, and respect for our laws, but we also need to avoid needless cruelty and endless red tape for families who are trying to do things the right way.

As someone who works with students and travelers from all over, I think our immigration policy should prioritize dignity, opportunity, and a clear, realistic path to citizenship for people who contribute to our communities. We ought to protect borders in a fair, humane way while expanding legal avenues for work, study, and refuge, especially for those fleeing violence or climate disasters. A modern path to citizenship should reward long-term residence, clean records, and community involvement, and we should make the process affordable and transparent so it’s not just accessible to the wealthy. That approach reflects both our history as a nation of immigrants and the diverse, vibrant campuses and cities I see every day.

As a Cambodian immigrant who worked hard to become a naturalized U.S. citizen, I believe immigration policy should balance compassion with strict enforcement of the law. We should welcome those who follow legal processes, pass background checks, contribute to our economy, and respect American values and traditions. The path to citizenship should be clear, merit-based, and fair, so that people who play by the rules and work hard have a real chance. At the same time, we must secure our borders and consistently enforce immigration laws to protect our communities and the integrity of our system.

I think immigration policy should balance compassion with practicality, making sure people who come here are treated humanely while our communities and natural resources aren’t stretched past their limits. There should be a clear, realistic path to citizenship for those who work hard, follow the law, and want to contribute, especially families raising kids here. We also need to consider how population growth affects the environment and quality of life, so policies should encourage sustainable planning and respect for the land.

I think immigration policy ought to put American citizens first, protect our borders, and make sure people follow the law just like I had to follow the rules in my time. I’m not against folks coming here for a better life, but the path to citizenship should be earned through hard work, learning our language and history, paying taxes, and showing real loyalty to this country.

I think our immigration policy should balance strong border security and enforcement with a fair, realistic path to citizenship for people who follow the rules, work hard, and contribute to our communities. As someone who works in a factory and comes from Polish roots myself, I respect legal processes and want everyone held to the same standards, but I also believe in treating people with dignity and giving those already here, paying taxes, and staying out of trouble a chance to come out of the shadows. A good system would prioritize background checks, English learning, and steady employment, while avoiding extremes on either side and keeping families together whenever possible.

I think immigration rules should be fair and kind, because my religion teaches me to care about people and I’d want others to help my family if we had to move somewhere new. People who follow the laws, work hard, and want to be part of our communities should have a clear and not-too-complicated way to become citizens. Kids especially should feel safe and welcome, no matter where they were born.

Immigration policy should balance compassion with practical oversight, offering a clear, reasonable path to citizenship for people who work hard, follow the law, and contribute to our economy and communities. As someone who works in finance and understands how much immigrant labor and entrepreneurship support our markets, I believe we should streamline legal processes, protect families from unnecessary separation, and prioritize humane treatment at the border. At the same time, we need effective, fair enforcement and background checks so the system maintains public trust and doesn’t disadvantage those who have gone through the legal process.

As someone who works every day with students and families, I believe immigration policy and the path to citizenship should be orderly, humane, and realistic about the needs of both newcomers and the communities that receive them. We should prioritize clear rules, background checks, and respect for the law, while also providing a fair, attainable path to citizenship for those who work, contribute, and are raising children here—especially if those children are in our schools. I support policies that keep families together, ensure access to education and basic mental health services, and encourage new citizens to fully participate in and strengthen our local communities.

As a Black man from North Carolina whose family history is rooted in struggles for basic rights, I think immigration policy should be grounded in fairness, human dignity, and equal opportunity. We should have a clear, humane path to citizenship that doesn’t tear families apart, protects workers from exploitation, and recognizes how much immigrants contribute to education, our economy, and our culture.

As a Hispanic, U.S.-born nurse in a busy hospital, I see every day how immigrants strengthen our healthcare system and our communities, so immigration policy should be fair, orderly, and firmly rooted in both compassion and the rule of law. We need a clear, realistic path to citizenship for people who work hard, pay taxes, and have built their lives here—especially those in essential fields like healthcare—while maintaining secure borders and reasonable screening. As a Protestant and a mom, I believe our laws should reflect both responsibility and mercy, giving families stability and keeping them together whenever possible.

Immigration policy should be guided by basic fairness, respect for human dignity, and a clear, realistic path to citizenship for people who work, pay taxes, and contribute to our communities. As someone raising kids on my own and managing properties in a diverse city, I see firsthand how immigrants keep neighborhoods and local economies running, and I think we should reward that with legal stability, not punishment or fear. We need strong but humane border enforcement, plus a streamlined, affordable process so families aren’t stuck in limbo for years.

As an immigrant, a mother, and a scientist, I believe immigration policy and the path to citizenship should be fair, humane, and firmly rooted in both evidence and respect for human dignity. We should prioritize family unity, offer a clear and reasonable path to citizenship for long-term, law-abiding residents and contributors to our economy, and protect refugees and asylum seekers. Good policy must also invest in language access, education, and workforce integration so that newcomers can fully participate and innovate, just as I’ve been able to do in my work developing new medicines.

As a cop, a dad, and the grandson of immigrants, I think our immigration policy should be both tough and fair: secure borders and efficient enforcement, but no cruelty or chaos. We need a clear, realistic path to citizenship for people who work, pay taxes, follow the law, and have built lives here—especially Dreamers and long‑time residents—because they’re already part of our communities. A functional system should prioritize human dignity, family unity, and economic need, not fearmongering or political theater.

My parents tell me that our church teaches every person is made in God’s image and deserves to be treated with love and fairness, no matter where they’re from. I think immigration policy and the path to citizenship should help families stay together and give kids like me a safe place to grow, play, and belong, while still having clear rules that people can follow.

As someone who was born here to a Mexican family and works hard in construction, I think immigration policy should be firm but fair, focused on giving people who contribute to our communities a real, attainable path to citizenship. We should prioritize keeping families together, protecting workers from exploitation, and offering undocumented people who pay taxes and follow the law a chance to come out of the shadows. Given our history as a country of immigrants, it’s only right that our laws reflect dignity, opportunity, and respect for those who are already part of the fabric of our neighborhoods.

As a Catholic and the daughter of Scottish immigrants, I believe our immigration policy should balance compassion with order and respect for the rule of law. We should welcome those who come legally, are willing to work hard, embrace American values, and contribute to our communities, while securing the border and enforcing our laws fairly. A path to citizenship should be structured, earned, and not reward illegal entry, but it should also recognize the dignity of each person and keep families together whenever possible.

As someone who worked hard to build a successful career and values law, order, and personal responsibility, I believe immigration policy should prioritize secure borders, strict enforcement, and a merit-based system that attracts those who can contribute to our economy and respect our values. A path to citizenship should be structured, earned, and conditional on learning English, following our laws, and demonstrating a commitment to American principles, not granted automatically or used as a political bargaining chip.

I think immigration policy should be fair and humane, treating people with dignity no matter where they come from or how much money they have. There should be a clear and realistic path to citizenship for people who work hard, follow the law, and want to contribute to their communities, especially families and kids who’ve grown up here. Since I care a lot about the environment, I also think we should plan for how population changes affect things like housing and natural resources, instead of just blaming immigrants. Overall, the rules should focus on equality, safety, and giving people a real chance at a better life.

As someone who cares deeply about people and the planet, I think immigration policy should balance compassion, fairness, and sustainability. We should have a clear, accessible path to citizenship for those who work, contribute to their communities, respect human rights, and are willing to be part of a more environmentally responsible society. At the same time, policy should be honest about resource limits and climate impacts, prioritizing humane treatment, family unity, and support for refugees and climate migrants.

As someone who spent a career enforcing the law and protecting my community, I believe immigration policy must start with secure borders, clear rules, and consistent enforcement so people know our laws mean something. I welcome those who come legally, work hard, learn English, and respect our values, and I think the path to citizenship should reward that commitment while not giving an advantage to those who break the rules. At the same time, we should remain compassionate, especially toward families and those fleeing real danger, balancing mercy with order and fairness to American citizens.

Creo que las personas que vienen a este país deben ser tratadas con cariño y justicia, como cuando compartimos los juguetes en el parque. Mis papás me dicen que muchas familias solo quieren un lugar seguro para trabajar, vivir tranquilos y que sus hijos vayan a la escuela, igual que yo. Pienso que las leyes deberían ayudar a las familias buenas a quedarse juntas y encontrar una forma clara y ordenada de ser parte de este país, porque Jesús nos enseña a amar al prójimo.

As a Catholic and a conservative, I believe our immigration policy should uphold both the rule of law and the dignity of every human person. We need strong, secure borders and a clear, orderly system so people come here the right way, respect our laws, and work toward learning our language and embracing American values. I support a tough but fair path to citizenship that includes background checks, paying taxes, and demonstrating commitment to this country, while also keeping families together when possible.

As a Catholic and a conservative, I believe our immigration policy should balance compassion with the rule of law: strong, secure borders and clear enforcement, but also a fair, orderly system that respects the dignity of those who follow the rules. Legal immigration should be encouraged, with a path to citizenship for people who come here lawfully, work, learn English, embrace American values, and contribute to their communities. I don’t think those who break the law to enter should be rewarded with an easy path, but I also think we need realistic solutions that keep families together and support our economy.

Immigration policy should balance compassion with practicality: we need a clear, enforceable system that welcomes people who want to contribute to our communities and respect our laws, while ensuring we have the resources to support both new arrivals and current residents. A fair path to citizenship should include learning English, understanding our civic institutions, paying taxes, and following the law, with reasonable timelines and transparent criteria. I also think we should prioritize refugees and migrants displaced by environmental crises and conflict, reflecting both our moral responsibility and the realities of a changing planet. As a parent and educator, I want policies that protect opportunity, social stability, and the natural environment for the next generation.

As a Black Catholic kid from Maryland who’s seen how hard people work just to get by, I think immigration policy should be guided by fairness, compassion, and basic respect for human dignity. We should have a clear, realistic path to citizenship that doesn’t tear families apart, protects workers from exploitation, and recognizes that immigrants strengthen our communities and economy. At the same time, the system should be orderly and consistent, so people who follow the rules have a real shot and aren’t stuck in limbo for years.

Immigration policy should prioritize individual responsibility, legal order, and contribution to the community—if you come here ready to work hard, respect the law, and support yourself and your family, there ought to be a clear, efficient path to stay and eventually become a citizen. We should secure the border and enforce the rules we have, but we should also cut the red tape so honest, skilled people who want to build businesses, pay taxes, and add to our economy and culture can do so without being buried in bureaucracy.

I think immigration rules should be fair and kind, especially to families and kids, because everyone deserves a safe place to live and grow. Since my parents and grandparents worked hard to give us a better life here, I think people who follow the laws, work hard, and want to be good neighbors should have a clear and not-too-complicated way to become citizens.

I think immigration rules should be fair and clear so families who follow the law and work hard can have a real chance to become citizens. Since my family and friends are important to me, I believe we should keep people safe and check who comes in, but also be kind and help kids and families who need a better life.

As the grandson of Texans who lived through segregation and fought to claim rights that were supposedly already theirs, I think any immigration policy has to start from a simple principle: people are people before they are paperwork. A just system should be humane, clearly structured, and realistically enforceable, with an earned but attainable path to citizenship that rewards contribution, family unity, and community ties rather than wealth or luck. We should prioritize due process, reject scapegoating immigrants for broader economic failures, and invest in integration—language access, education, and civic participation—so new citizens can fully participate in and strengthen our democracy.

I think our immigration policy should balance compassion with responsibility: we should welcome people who are willing to work hard, follow the law, and contribute to our communities, while also maintaining strong, fair border security. A reasonable, clearly defined path to citizenship—especially for long-term residents, DACA recipients, and families—should include background checks, paying taxes, learning English, and civic education so new citizens are set up to thrive and participate fully.

As a Catholic, a mom, and someone who believes in giving folks a fair shot, I think our immigration policy should balance compassion with common sense and security. We need a clear, humane path to citizenship for undocumented immigrants who work hard, follow the rules, and are raising families here, along with strong protections for DREAMers. At the same time, we should invest in an efficient, orderly legal immigration system that matches our economic needs—especially in industries like mine—while treating every person with dignity and respect.

As someone who has lived her whole life in Minnesota and seen how immigrants enrich our schools, neighborhoods, and churches, I believe our immigration policy should be fair, humane, and realistic. We should have secure, orderly borders and clear rules, but we must also provide a reasonable, affordable path to citizenship for hardworking people who follow the law, contribute to their communities, and want to raise their families here. Guided by my faith and belief in the dignity of every person, I think families should be kept together whenever possible, and those who have built a life here over many years deserve a chance to fully belong.

As someone who believes deeply in holistic wellbeing, I think our immigration policy should balance compassion with practicality, recognizing that healthy communities are enriched by cultural diversity and the talents of newcomers. We should provide a clear, humane, and efficient path to citizenship for people who follow the rules, contribute to society, and seek safety or opportunity, including strong support for families and refugees. At the same time, we need fair, consistent enforcement and transparent standards so immigrants and citizens alike can trust the system.

I think immigration rules should be fair and organized so people who want to come here peacefully, work hard, and follow the laws can have a real chance to become citizens. Families shouldn’t be split up, and kids especially should be protected and given opportunities, like school and health care. Since my parents moved here and I was born abroad, I feel like people who love this country and respect its values should be welcomed, not treated like they don’t belong.

As someone who’s always believed in community and fairness, I think our immigration policy should balance strong, sensible border security with a humane, practical path to citizenship for people who work hard, follow the law, and contribute to our society. We’re a nation built by immigrants, and folks who’ve put down roots here—raising families, paying taxes, helping local businesses—deserve a clear, affordable way to become citizens without living in fear.

As a Texan, a small business owner, and the child of Irish ancestry, I believe our immigration policy should balance strong, orderly border management with a humane, realistic path to citizenship. We should prioritize fair, efficient legal pathways for people who work, pay taxes, and contribute to our communities—especially those who’ve built lives here and whose kids go to school alongside mine. A modernized system that includes background checks, reasonable waiting periods, and a clear route to full civic participation reflects both our economic interests and our moral responsibility as a country built by immigrants.

As a police officer and the son of Vietnamese immigrants, I believe immigration policy should be firm, orderly, and rule-based, but also fair to those who follow the process and contribute to our communities. We need secure borders, strict enforcement against illegal entry, and a streamlined, merit-based legal system that prioritizes public safety, economic contribution, and respect for American laws and values. A path to citizenship should exist, but it should be earned through background checks, steady employment, English proficiency, and a demonstrated commitment to this country.

As someone who believes deeply in equality and community, I think our immigration policy and path to citizenship should be fair, humane, and realistic about the economic and social contributions immigrants make. We should secure our borders and enforce laws, but also provide a clear, accessible path to citizenship for people who work hard, follow the rules, and put down roots here—especially families with children. Our policies should avoid scapegoating and instead focus on integrating newcomers through language support, job opportunities, and civic education so they can fully participate in and strengthen our communities.

My mommy and daddy tell me that our family came from faraway a long time ago, so I think people who want to live here should be treated kindly and fairly. I think immigration rules should help families stay together and let people who follow the rules and work hard become citizens. People should be safe and not scared, and everyone should get a chance to belong.

I think immigration rules should be fair and kind, especially to families and kids, because it would be really scary to grow up afraid of being separated from your parents. If people follow the laws, work hard, and try to learn the language and help their communities, there should be a clear and not-too-complicated way for them to become citizens.

I think immigration policy should be fair and humane, because a lot of people come here looking for safety and better opportunities, just like my family wants better for me. The path to citizenship should be clear, affordable, and not take forever, especially for kids who grew up here and feel American already. At the same time, the government should do background checks and keep people safe without treating immigrants like criminals just for wanting a better life. Overall, our laws should match our values of equality and respect, no matter where someone was born.

As someone who came to this country from Ireland and became a citizen through naturalization, I believe immigration policy should be fair, humane, and provide a realistic, timely path to citizenship for people who work hard, follow the rules, and contribute to their communities. We should prioritize keeping families together, protecting refugees and asylum seekers, and treating all newcomers with dignity, regardless of where they’re from. At the same time, we need clear, well-enforced laws and enough resources so that the system is orderly rather than chaotic, instead of punishing people who simply seek a better life like I once did.

As a Vietnamese immigrant who naturalized here, I believe immigration policy should be rooted in fairness, humanity, and respect for the contributions immigrants make to this country. The path to citizenship should be clear, affordable, and timely, with special consideration for families, refugees, and long-term residents who already live, work, and pay taxes here. We should prioritize due process and protect human rights at the border, while also investing in language, job training, and civic education so newcomers can fully participate in and strengthen our communities.

As someone who works hard to support my family and cares deeply about fairness and opportunity, I think immigration policy should balance strong, secure borders with a humane, efficient path to citizenship for people who follow the rules and want to contribute. We should prioritize family unity, worker protections, and respect for human dignity, including for immigrants with disabilities, while also making sure employers can’t exploit anyone—citizen or not.

As someone who came here from Mexico and worked hard to become a U.S. citizen, I believe immigration policy should respect the law, protect our borders, and still offer a clear, fair path for those who follow the rules. People who want to live here should learn English as best they can, contribute through work, respect our Christian values and traditions, and show loyalty to this country. I support helping families stay together and making the process more straightforward, but I also think we must be strict about illegal entry and make sure citizenship is earned, not given away.

As an attorney and a proud Californian, I believe immigration policy and a path to citizenship should be grounded in the rule of law, basic human dignity, and economic realism. We need a clear, efficient legal pathway that prioritizes family unity, protects refugees and asylum seekers, and recognizes the contributions of long-term, law-abiding undocumented residents by giving them a fair, earned route to citizenship. At the same time, enforcement should be rational and focused on genuine security threats, not on criminalizing people whose only offense is seeking a better life and contributing to our communities.

Mi mami y mi papi dicen que este país nos cuida y que todos los que vienen buscando una vida mejor merecen ser tratados con respeto y cariño, como Jesús nos enseña. Pienso que si las personas trabajan, siguen las reglas y quieren ser parte de aquí, deberían tener una manera justa y clara de ser ciudadanos, para que sus niños puedan estar seguros, ir a la escuela y dibujar sin miedo.

I think immigration policy should be fair, humane, and give people a real chance to build a better life, especially families and kids who are just trying to be safe and go to school like me. There should be a clear, affordable path to citizenship that doesn’t take forever or treat people like they’re criminals just for wanting opportunity. My faith teaches me to welcome the stranger and care about human dignity, so I believe we should focus on keeping families together and judging people by their character and contributions, not where they were born.

As a naturalized citizen who came here from Mexico, I believe immigration policy should be firm but fair, with secure borders and clear, consistently enforced laws so people enter the right way. Those who follow the rules, work hard, pay taxes, and respect American values should have a structured path to citizenship, while those who break serious laws should face consequences. We also need to prioritize families so parents and children can stay together, and ensure that newcomers are prepared to contribute and integrate into our communities.

As a Catholic and the daughter of Michigan immigrants myself, I believe our immigration policy should balance compassion with order: protecting human dignity, keeping families together, and offering a clear, realistic path to citizenship for those who contribute to our communities. We should prioritize humane treatment at the border, fair asylum procedures, and sensible background checks, while also recognizing that newcomers enrich our culture—much like new voices and ideas enrich art.

I think immigration policy should balance keeping the country safe with being fair and kind to people who want a better life, because my family’s always taught me that everyone is equal in God’s eyes. There should be background checks and clear rules, but if people work hard, follow the laws, and really want to be part of our communities, there should be a clear and realistic path to citizenship.

I think immigration rules should make sure people are safe and kind, like letting families stay together and helping kids go to school and be healthy. If people want to live here and follow the rules, work hard, and be good neighbors, they should have a fair and not-too-scary way to become citizens.

Immigration policy should put the safety and economic security of American citizens first, with strict border enforcement and clear rules that are actually followed. I’m not against people coming here the right way—this country was built by immigrants—but there needs to be a tough, orderly process that rewards hard work, respect for our laws, and learning our language. The path to citizenship should be earned over time, with background checks, steady employment, and a real commitment to American values.

I think immigration policy should balance compassion and fairness, recognizing that many people come here seeking safety and opportunity, just like my own family generations ago. There should be a clear, affordable, and realistic path to citizenship for people who follow the rules, work hard, and contribute to their communities, including Dreamers who grew up here. At the same time, we should have secure, orderly borders and make decisions based on facts and human rights, not fear or stereotypes.

I think our immigration policy should be humane and fair, with a clear, realistic path to citizenship for people who work hard, follow the rules, and contribute to our communities. Growing up here and watching this country change, I’ve seen how immigrants often take on tough jobs and enrich our culture, and they deserve a chance to belong fully. We should secure the border sensibly, but not at the expense of treating people with dignity or breaking up families.

Immigration policy should put the safety and stability of our communities first, with secure borders and strict enforcement of existing laws. I support a clear, orderly legal process for coming here and earning citizenship—one that prioritizes people who follow the rules, contribute to our economy, respect our laws, and are willing to fully integrate into American society.

I believe immigration policy should put American citizens’ safety, jobs, and resources first, with strict border security and clear enforcement of the laws we already have. I’m not against people coming here for a better life, but they should follow the legal process, respect our values, learn English, and work hard. The path to citizenship should be earned over time through steady employment, clean records, and commitment to this country, not given away just because someone made it across the border.

I think immigration policy should be fair, humane, and realistic, recognizing that a lot of people are just looking for safety and opportunity like my own family did generations ago. There should be a clear, affordable, and efficient path to citizenship for people who work, follow the law, and contribute to their communities, instead of trapping them in limbo for years. At the same time, the system should protect basic security and make sure we have the resources—like schools, healthcare, and jobs—to support both current residents and new arrivals. Overall, the focus should be on dignity, integration, and shared responsibility, not fear or scapegoating.

As a lifelong Virginian and a Catholic, I believe immigration policy should balance compassion with respect for the rule of law. We should prioritize secure borders, thorough vetting, and a fair, orderly system that encourages legal immigration and rewards those who follow the rules. A path to citizenship should be possible, but it ought to require learning English, paying taxes, and demonstrating respect for American values and our Constitution. This way we protect our communities while still honoring the dignity of people who want to become Americans the right way.

As a progressive and a policy analyst working in higher education, I think immigration policy and the path to citizenship should be guided by fairness, human dignity, and economic reality. We should provide a clear, attainable, and timely pathway to citizenship for long-term residents, students, and workers who contribute to our communities, while prioritizing due process and family unity. At the same time, policy should be evidence-based rather than fear-driven, focusing resources on genuine security threats instead of criminalizing people whose only “offense” is seeking opportunity or safety.

As someone who came to this country as an immigrant and works hard every day, I believe immigration policy should be rooted in dignity, fairness, and realism. We need a clear, affordable, and timely path to citizenship for people who follow the rules, pay taxes, and contribute to their communities, instead of trapping them in years of uncertainty. The system should protect human rights, keep families together, and recognize the value that diverse cultures and skills bring to America—because people like me aren’t a burden, we’re an investment in the country’s future.

Immigration policy should be humane, fair, and rooted in the idea that people deserve a real chance to build a life if they’re willing to contribute and follow the rules. As someone who works in the arts and cares about diversity and creativity, I think we should make the path to citizenship clear, efficient, and accessible—especially for families, refugees, and long-term residents who are already part of our communities. We also need strong worker protections so immigrants aren’t exploited and wages don’t get driven down, and we should reject policies based on fear or racism. From a Buddhist perspective, compassion and reducing suffering should be at the core of how we treat people who come to this country seeking safety and opportunity.

As someone who worked hard all my life and values law, order, and personal responsibility, I believe immigration policy should prioritize secure borders, thorough vetting, and strict enforcement of existing laws. We should welcome those who come legally, are willing to work, respect our traditions, and contribute to our communities, but not reward those who break the rules. A fair path to citizenship should be structured, merit-based, and clear, with expectations for learning English, embracing American values, and becoming self-sufficient.

I think immigration policy should be realistic and fair: we need strong border security and clear rules, but also an efficient, predictable path to legal status and eventually citizenship for people who work hard, pay taxes, and follow the law. As someone who sees how many jobs depend on reliable, motivated workers, I believe we should prioritize immigrants who are contributing to the economy and our communities, while making sure the system isn’t chaotic or easily abused.

Immigration policy should be guided by fairness and basic human dignity, making sure people who work hard, follow the law, and contribute to their communities have a real, achievable path to citizenship. We should protect refugees and families, not tear them apart, and avoid treating immigrants like they’re less deserving just because they weren’t born here. At the same time, we can have reasonable security checks and clear rules, but those rules should be applied consistently and without discrimination.

I think people who want to live here should be nice, follow the rules, and try to help others, just like we learn to do at school. If families are trying to be safe and have a better life, we should try to help them and let them become part of our country if they work hard and are kind. It’s important that everyone who comes here learns our language and our laws so we can all get along and be fair to each other.

I think people who want to live here should be treated fairly and kindly, especially families and kids. There should be rules so everyone is safe and follows the law, but the rules shouldn’t be so hard that good people can never become citizens. If someone works hard, helps others, and wants to be part of our country, we should give them a real chance to stay.

As someone who immigrated here legally and worked many years in a factory before retiring, I believe immigration policy should first protect our borders, follow the law strictly, and prioritize those who respect our rules and want to contribute. The path to citizenship should be orderly, require learning English, understanding our history and values, and proving you can support yourself, so that becoming an American remains something earned and cherished.

I think immigration rules should be fair and kind, because my parents always tell me everyone deserves a chance to feel safe and have a good life. People who come here, follow the rules, work hard, and care about others should have a way to become citizens so they can belong and not be scared.

As someone who’s built a decent life and small business in this country, I believe immigration policy should balance compassion with order: clear, fair rules, strong borders, and a humane, realistic path to citizenship for people who work hard, follow the law, and contribute to their communities. A modern, efficient system with background checks, labor protections, and reasonable timelines would strengthen our economy, reflect our values as a nation of immigrants, and give people already rooted here a chance to step out of the shadows and fully participate in American life.

Immigration policy should prioritize the rule of law, security, and the economic needs of our country, while still reflecting America’s tradition as a nation of opportunity. We need a system that strictly enforces the border and employment laws, favors legal applicants who can contribute skills our economy needs, and ensures they fully embrace our values, language, and civic responsibilities. A path to citizenship should be earned through documented lawful behavior over time, taxpaying work, and clear loyalty to the United States.

As an immigrant, an educator, and a mom, I believe our immigration policy and path to citizenship should be grounded in dignity, fairness, and opportunity. We need clear, efficient, and humane processes that keep families together, protect refugees and the most vulnerable, and recognize the contributions of those who work, pay taxes, and build community here—regardless of where they were born. A just system should also include a realistic, compassionate pathway to citizenship for long-term residents, especially those who’ve grown up in our schools and are already part of the fabric of this country.

As a nurse and a mom, I think our immigration policy should balance compassion with practicality: we need secure, efficient systems that protect public safety while recognizing the humanity of people who come here seeking a better life. There should be a clear, affordable, and timely path to citizenship for long-term, law-abiding residents, including DREAMers and essential workers who already contribute to our communities and health care system.

As someone who works in manufacturing and is raising young kids, I think our immigration policy and path to citizenship should balance compassion with clear, consistent rules. We should have an efficient, humane process that protects workers from exploitation, keeps families together, and welcomes people who want to contribute to our economy and communities. A fair path to citizenship should include background checks, paying taxes, and learning our laws and language, while recognizing the dignity and humanity of those already here. In line with my environmental and social justice values, I also think we need to address the global inequalities and conflicts that push people to migrate in the first place.

I think immigration rules should be fair and kind, especially to families and kids, because nobody chooses where they’re born. People who work hard, follow the laws, and want to be part of this country should have a clear and not-too-complicated way to become citizens. It’s important that families aren’t separated and that kids can grow up feeling safe and like they belong.

As someone who cares deeply about both personal freedom and community, I think our immigration policy should balance compassion with clear, fair rules. We ought to have a straightforward and attainable path to citizenship for people who work hard, follow the law, and contribute to our society—much like the families I see every day in our schools and neighborhoods. At the same time, we should ensure the process is orderly, secure, and humane, reflecting our values as a nation built on opportunity and mutual respect.

As someone who grew up in California and volunteers in my community, I believe our immigration policy should balance compassion with common sense: welcoming those who contribute, follow the rules, and seek a better life, while maintaining secure and orderly borders. A fair, realistic path to citizenship should be available for long-term, law-abiding immigrants and Dreamers, with clear requirements like background checks, learning English, and paying taxes, because they’re already part of our neighborhoods, churches, and schools.

As someone who has spent a lifetime studying how complex systems function, I believe immigration policy should be guided by human dignity, family unity, and an honest assessment of our social and ecological carrying capacities. We should provide a clear, fair, and timely path to citizenship for those who work, study, and contribute to our communities, with special compassion for refugees and the undocumented who have built lives here. Our laws ought to reflect Catholic social teaching on welcoming the stranger, while also planning responsibly so that new residents and longstanding communities alike have access to clean air, water, and opportunity. A just immigration system strengthens democracy by embracing diversity and ensuring that all who are part of our society can fully participate in its civic and political life.

As someone who believes in law and order and worked hard to build my own small business, I think immigration policy should prioritize securing the border, enforcing existing laws, and making sure we know exactly who is coming into the country and why. I support a fair but firm path to citizenship that rewards those who follow the rules, contribute to our economy, and are willing to embrace American values, language, and culture.

Immigration policy should be grounded in human dignity, fairness, and a clear, realistic path to citizenship for people who contribute to our communities and economy. As someone who works in a creative industry and values diversity and inclusion, I believe we’re stronger when we welcome immigrants, protect refugees, and treat mixed‑status families with compassion rather than fear. We should streamline legal pathways, protect workers from exploitation, and offer an attainable, well-defined route to citizenship for long-term residents, including Dreamers.

I think immigration policy should balance being fair and humane with keeping the country safe and stable. People who work hard, follow the laws, and contribute to their communities should have a clear, realistic path to citizenship, not be stuck in limbo for years. Families shouldn’t be torn apart, and kids who grow up here, go to school here, and call this place home should have a real chance to belong. At the same time, the government should do proper background checks and make sure the system isn’t abused so people don’t feel like the rules don’t matter.

As a Catholic and a conservative, I believe immigration policy should balance compassion with respect for the rule of law and the stability of our communities. We should welcome those who come legally, work hard, and embrace our language, civic traditions, and responsibilities, while firmly enforcing our borders and immigration laws. A fair, orderly path to citizenship ought to prioritize security checks, economic self-sufficiency, and genuine commitment to American values, not political advantage.

As a Catholic and a public school teacher, I believe our immigration policy and path to citizenship should reflect both compassion and fairness: we should protect human dignity, keep families together, and offer a realistic, structured path to legal status for those who contribute to our communities. At the same time, we need secure, orderly borders, clear rules that are enforced consistently, and a system that doesn’t undercut American workers or turn immigration into a political football.

As a public school teacher and the granddaughter of Spanish immigrants, I believe our immigration policy and path to citizenship should be humane, fair, and rooted in the reality that immigrants strengthen our communities and classrooms. We should prioritize family unity, a clear and affordable route to citizenship for long-term residents (including undocumented neighbors who contribute and follow the law), and protections for refugees and asylum seekers, while investing in integration—like language support and education—so new Americans can fully thrive and participate in our democracy.
